description:
Anser brachyrhynchus, commonly known as the pink-footed goose, is a species of goose that belongs to the genus Anser. This migratory bird is native to the Arctic regions of Europe and Asia, breeding primarily in Greenland, Iceland, and Svalbard.

The pink-footed goose is a medium-sized waterfowl with a distinctive appearance. Its most notable feature is its short, pink bill, which gives the species its common name. The plumage of the pink-footed goose is predominantly gray, with a pinkish-gray head and neck, and black wingtips. The legs and feet are also pink, which helps to distinguish this species from other similar-looking geese.

These geese are well-adapted to their Arctic breeding grounds, with a robust body and strong wings that allow them to navigate the harsh environmental conditions. They feed primarily on grasses, sedges, and other vegetation, as well as agricultural crops during their migratory periods.

The pink-footed goose is an important species in the Arctic ecosystem, playing a role in the cycling of nutrients and the dispersal of seeds. Its conservation status is currently listed as Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), but the species is closely monitored due to the potential impacts of climate change and other environmental factors on its breeding and wintering grounds.
